title: Wednesday, 10th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

PM

11:03 am

Cut and paste for tight non-subscribers here...

PM

The Bank of England intends to make up a shortfall in its new bond-buying programme later in the year and will continue its third day of purchases as planned after its latest quantitative easing efforts ran into trouble.

In an update this morning, the BoE said it would make up for a £52m shortfall in gilt purchases in the second half of this year. Some investors played hard ball over parting with the gilts just two days into the BoE’s resumption of its £70bn quantitative easing programme – £60bn of which is concentrated on government bonds (you can read more from the FT here).

However the plan got off to a bad start on Tuesday when investors offered to sell the BoE £1.12bn of long-dated gilts – below the £1.17bn the bank was targeting. Investors in long-dated gilts include pension funds which must hold the bonds to match future liabilities and which have faced growing deficits as the yields on global government bonds fall to record lows, reports Elaine Moore.

PM

Izy points out that this looks like Gresham's Law in action

https://en.wikiped...ki/Gresham%27s_law

BE

So, Exhibit A, from your super soaraway FT less than a month ago.

BE

A revival of takeover rumours helped lift Entertainment One to a six-month high on Tuesday.
Talk that ITV has renewed its interest in Entertainment One, owner of the Peppa Pig cartoon franchise, squeezed the stock 4.1 per cent higher to 201.5p as more than three times the daily average changed hands.
One version of the rumour had ITV’s advisers working on a potential £1bn hostile offer, a 20 per cent premium to the current valuation.
An ITV spokeswoman said the company did not comment on rumours and speculation.
ITV (up 2.7 per cent to 190.7p) was reported in April to have held talks with Entertainment One about possible deals, though the Canadian company said then that no approach had been received.

BE

Let me get some sellside up here. Most of it saying, "huh?"

BE

Here's Liberum saying ITV probably won't bump.

BE

Because it looks a rubbish deal. But then, that's what the sellside was telling us before it happened, and it still happened.

11:20 am
BE

ITV has confirmed it has made a bid for Entertainment One but gave no indication as to whether it will now up its bid following its rejection. We suspect it will not although there is some rationale for a combination of the assets. Reiterate Buy.

BE

ITV has put out a statement confirming it bid for Entertainment One at 236p per share, or £1,030m market capitalisation (with the bid valuing E One at c. £1.2bn (including £182m of net debt) or c. 10x EV / March 2016 EBITDA). Tis follows Entertainment One’s earlier statement confirming ITV was the bidder.

BE

ITV stated that the offer “represented a significant premium over the undisturbed eOne share price” and that, as usual in these situations, it reserves the right to amend its offer or withdraw it. We think ITV may not be prepared to pay the £3+ per share that we believe many E One shareholders want. A major acquisition would also put the question of ITV’s special dividend (10p per share for FY15) into question although ITV did increase the interim ordinary dividend by 26% yoy suggesting it is confident about its ability to pay out a substantial amount in dividends moving forwards.

11:20 am
BE

ITV noted in its release that “the proposed combination with eOne has strong strategic rationale” and that a key part of its strategy is “continuing to build a scaled international content and global distribution business”. However, there is a strong argument for saying that ITV may only want the TV assets (including Mark Gordon, which was responsible for shows such as “Ray Donovan” and “Grey’s Anatomy”) and is not interested in the Film assets, where have seen a mixed operational performance and where there have been investor questions around the cashflow. A more interesting question is whether ITV would want to retain the “Peppa Pig” franchise or would look to sell it to a more children’s-orientated company.

BE

We talked quite recently, I think, about ITV's options ..... As in, diversify or be bought itself.

PM

Aside from the Pig thing and the Turkey divison, isnt this Mark Gordon Company the key target?

11:22 am

Yeah, that's certainly an ignored part of it. It's acquiring non-sterling earnings.

In 2015, The Mark Gordon Company partnered with Entertainment One (eOne) to create an independent television and film studio. Gordon serves as CEO of the company, which both finances and produces premium content by Gordon as well as other producers.

11:23 am
PM

That's just from Gordon's wiki

BE

Not sure about this idea that ITV isn't keen on the film assets either. Film distribution not that bad a business providing you can sort out the -- erm -- rather complicated funding structures.

BE

Let me grab some more sellside.

11:24 am
BE

Deutsche this time.

BE

Entertainment One (E-One, CMP:GBp217.5) has released a statement
confirming that it has received and rejected an offer for the company at 236p
per share. Reuters reports that the offer came from ITV and the FT is also today
reporting that ITV was the bidder. There have been prior reports of ITV’s
interest (FT, 14 April 2016). But this is the first confirmation of an actual bid.

BE

There is a reasonable case for ITV to be interested in E-One. It has a TV
production arm which has functional overlap with ITV Studios. There is also a
large programming library, valued by E-One’s independent consultants at
$801m which will boost ITV’s SVOD (subscription video on-demand) sales and
online audience/ad shares. While E-One stock has recovered strongly from the
low of 130p in February, it is still down c.40% from June 2015 peak (vs. Euro
Stoxx Media down 3%) following share sell-down from the core shareholder,
Marwyn, and rights issue for two major acquisitions. At 236p, the offer would
be 8.5x EV/EBITDA consensus 12m forward (consensus source: Reuters) which
is still below the 9-10x average for recent content acquisitions. So ITV’s bid
was not rich in valuation and it is not highly levered. So far so good?

11:25 am
BE

E-One, by FY15 EBITDA contribution is TV Production 20%, Licensing & Family
50%, and film production 30%. The licensing business is mainly the franchising
around a single hit, Peppa Pig. Children’s show licensing and tertiary rights
exploitation has little overlap with ITV’s production and format sales focus.
Offloading the film distribution business and a loss-making music operation
does not look easy should ITV end up acquiring the whole group. So the true
overlap is limited to the 20% of EBITDA from TV production and even here E-
One only seed finance and co-produce; they do not own end-to-end facilities
and rights. Industry feedback has been this model is getting more challenging
with a shrinking pool of co-production partners. Moreover, E-One is CF
negative and this, plus the £1.2bn EV at 236p could jeopardize further
exceptional dividends (as we are forecasting for this year and next).

BE

(@Boycott: that's post the approach, which with all due respect is irrelevant since the approach only went in yesterday.)

BE

We have argued that organic growth at ITV Studios has been weak and ROIC
has been questionable (see here). 1H16 results caused more concern; organic
decline of 4% was worse than we expected and ex internal sales was -12%.
Management also refused to commit to growth for FY16 or ’17. The lack of
organic growth is requiring heavier emphasis on acquisitions. In a UK & US
content market which has been consolidating, targets are getting harder to
find. The offer for E-One, with such limited functional overlap, looks a further
concerning indication of the challenges to ITV’s content-led strategy

11:26 am

11:32 am
BE

This is via Twitter a few months ago, post the Orlando nightclub shooting .....

BE

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

11:33 am
BE

Let me grab some Stifel to summarise.

BE

At first glance this looks like a good set of interim numbers with good organic growth and op. margin improvement. The interim dividend has been maintained - there had been concerns in some quarters that this may not be the case. Cash generation is much improved but leverage remains high. Plans remain in place to reduce this through internal initiatives.

BE

G4S reported solid organic revenue growth of 5.1% (guided range 4-6%)
taking sales to £3,086m. Emerging markets saw strong growth of +9.7% and
developed markets +2.4%. UK &Ireland is the only region seeing declining
sales. The company won contracts with an annual value of £0.7bn in the
period and the bid pipeline has been replenished to £6.3bn (£5.7bn FY15).
Group operating margins increased 180bps to 6.45% driven by the Cash
Solutions business (11.8% to 12.7%) with the Secure Solutions margin 10bps
lower at 6.1%. The next phase of G4S' productivity improvements will focus on
lean end to end processes in the manned security business which should drive
margin improvements in that segment.
No changes to provisions regarding onerous legacy contracts.
Reflecting the impact of strong working capital management, operating cash
flow increased 52% to £293m (£53m working capital inflow vs £64m outflow
1H15). This said leverage remains high at 3.2x, down from 3.3x with adverse
FX movements impacting progress. The message from the company remains
consistent, leverage will be reduced to 2.5x or lower in the next 12-18 months.
A key factor in reducing debt is asset disposals. In 1H16, 7 businesses were
sold for proceeds of £32m. At the prelims the company announced that it
expected to raise £250m-£350m over the next 12-14months from portfolio
management. Today's statement notes that: "we have a structured process
and active buyer interest in our remaining businesses held for sale".
Overall trading has been good in 1H16 but we suspect investors will want to
see more visible progress on the asset disposal programme and balance
sheet deleveraging.

11:33 am
BE

And RBC.

BE

H1 results are 1% ahead of us at the EBITA line driven by a slightly better organic growth (5.1% vs 4.1%) forecast and a slightly better margin performance,
although again messy given restatements, disposals and onerous contracts. Cashflow and the net debt position were better than feared with a working capital
inflow and less forex impact. As a result net debt is at the same level as the FY and although the IAS19 pension deficit has increased by £80m, commentary
around the upcoming actuarial review is more positive. Net debt to EBITDA has drooped a touch to 3.2x and management remains confident of still gleaning
£250-£350m from disposals over the next 18m. The dividend has been maintained. Whilst the balance sheet remains stretched, treading is fine and cashflow is
better and given the negative sentiment over the stock, I would expect it to be up today. We recently upgraded to Sector Perform (on July 25), believing risk
reward is more balanced given the valuation (11x 17E PE, 5% Div yield) if management could put the balance sheet issue to bed.
Sales - £3,086m vs forecast £3,071m
EBITA - £199m vs forecast £196.5m
Clean EPS – 6.6p vs forecast 6.0p (cons 14.5p)
DPS – 3,59p vs forecast 3.59p – flat
Sales: Organic revenue growth has come in at 5.1% vs 4.1% forecast and vs 3.6% at H215. Good growth was seen in most areas - Africa (7.4%), North
America (3.5%), Asia (3.4%) Middle East (16.4%), Europe ( 5.06%) and Latam (9.4%) with only the UIk weak at -1.9%

Margin: Ex disposals and onerous contracts, the EBITA margin was 6.45% vs 6.4% forecast – up 18bp on last year. Cash services margin increased by 90bp
although secure solutions was down 10bp
Exceptionals: Total exceptionals for the H1 were £11m
Net debt/Cash flow: Net debt was £1782m vs £1782m at the FY and vs £1984m forecast – a good performance – with less of an impact from forex than feared
and a good working capital performance (+£53m). Net debt to EBITDA now stands at 3.2x (vs 3.3x at the year end) although this is higher if include the pension
deficit.
Further disposals – Sold 7 businesses in H1 for £32m. No news on the bigger businesses held for resale other than ‘We have a structured process and active
buyer interest in our remaining businesses held for sale.’
Pension deficit: £314m net of tax vs £234m at FY –reflecting changes to discount rates and the deficit reduction payments. The latest actuarial review is due
in H2 but is expected to reflect strong asset performance and a reduction in the deficit
Outlook – Maintaining the 4-6% medium-term growth target and still expects to glean £250 to £350m from disposals over the next 18m.

BE

And Deutsche picks out a couple of bear points to pitch its sell recommendation again.

11:35 am
BE

The interim dividend of 3.59p was held flat which is not surprising given the
large working capital inflow in H1. We view the dividend payout as being at a
high level currently and think that it will likely be rebased lower to enable the
company to de-lever organically medium-term and enable some M&A.

BE

G4S only had £32m inflow from disposals in H1 from 7 businesses, compared
to a target by end-2017e of £250-350m. We believe that c.£10m was from the
ATM engineering business disposal, the rest generated from small disposals in
Finland, Kazakhstan, Brunei, Uzbekistan, Honduras and Thailand. Provision
utilisation was £57m in H1, of which £10m due to onerous contracts.

BE

G4S trades on a 2017e P/E of 12x, FCF to equity of 5.4% and dividend yield of
4.9%. We see risks to the dividend payout given the low FCF cover. We see
higher security demand in the world as a positive driver for security companies
but remain cautious on G4S due to an unresolved balance sheet and FCF
generation situation medium term. Sell.

11:35 am
BE

So, that's that.

BE

Rolls, for instance.

11:40 am
Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 787.50, up 24 (+3.14%), High: 793.00, Low: 767.00, Volume: 1.49m
PM

Top of the leader board

BE

Big rally on a rather downbeat sort of upgrade from Morgan Stanley.

11:40 am
PM

Ah, they're behind it

BE

(@ETI: your point would be stronger if you didn't mention two companies that have had rescue cash calls.)

BE

Here's the upshot.

11:42 am
BE

Increased confidence on cash generation: In our June note we highlighted that
there wasn't much room to manoeuvre before Rolls might be at risk of a further
credit rating downgrade by S&P. Post a better than expected 1H, boosted by
XWB engines sold as spares at a cash profit, we see an improved outlook for free
cash and are no longer as concerned. Further, having spent a reasonable amount
of time with the company post 1H, it is clear management has a better handle on
the levers that can be pulled for cash to improve going forward.

BE

Share price volatility highlights lack of valuation ceiling: While near-term
earnings multiples (15x 2018 PE vs peers 13x) that will likely expand with IFRS 15
(~19x 2018 PE) imply valuation ought to cap Rolls shares at best, we are no
longer convinced given the higher valuations yielded by a more fundamental
approach. Scope for sustained double-digit FCF growth at Rolls driven by
increasing aftermarket cash receipts means that while the yield is 3% in 2018
(MTU and Safran 6%), this rises to 12% by 2022 (MTU 8%, Safran 11%). Given
back-end loaded value potential with a heavy reliance on long-term assumptions:
share price volatility will be high; sentiment and trading momentum will remain
key... and on that front Rolls appears to have turned a corner.

BE

Next catalyst could be positive: This Autumn, Rolls will provide an update on the
transformation program, addressing the outlook for 2017 and 2018 in our view,
with building blocks that at least serve to underpin consensus if not to upgrade
it, thus providing additional confidence. Scope for additional cost savings also
seems likely to be addressed, something we don’t expect Rolls to rule out, even
if no further targets are set beyond the £200m by 2018.

11:42 am
BE

Why not OW? (i) While looking beyond 2020 we can find a valuation argument
to prefer Rolls, we like the better visibility and greater certainty at Safran, which
executing as is can generate 31% of its market cap in free cash in the next 5 years;
Rolls has to do a major turnaround to generate 16%; (ii) IFRS 15 could bring other
complications - our approach ‘looks through’, but rating agencies may not; (iii) No
room for error - improving cash flows are easy to model, but cycle (esp. in wide-
body) and incremental investment risks weigh, alongside execution.

BE

Morgan Stanley's house broker.

undefined

PM

Meeting and to appoint David Shearer as a director.

11:51 am
BE

(@jcb: that reading of the Code seems highly convenient and not reflective of its purpose. Under your interpretation, the Panel shouldn't have had the jurisdiction to make interventions on Shire-AbbVie, for instance. But it did. A lot.)

BE

So ............ What else do we have? Not a lot of corporate around, as you say.

PM

(That's a good point Bryce on AbbVie)

11:53 am
BE

So, we have Regus.

PM

(But I still don't think Crispin's going over this)

BE

(The lobbying campaign's only just started. Give me time.)

11:54 am
BE

We have Q2 results showing some deceleration of the business.

BE

Which as we know is extremely cyclical, so any kind of trend gets extrapolated.

BE

RBC can summarise where we are.

11:55 am
BE

H1 results are ahead of our expectations at the EBITA level (£90m vs £82m forecast). This was primarily due to a better overhead performance with SG&A
actually down 6% YoY. Growth has slowed in Q2, with management reporting a softening of demand (Q1 mature growth 2.7%, H1 0.9%, so Q2 -1%) and gross
margins have also been impacted by new openings, as expected, and a greater level of partnership agreements. Regus spent £83m on 113 new centres and
has visibility on £120m and 350 centres so far this year, which is unchanged from May. The outlook points to some softening in demand but management
believes the efficiency gains will offset and hence expectations for the year are unchanged. Currency is also a tailwind at present. We remain positive - Regus
has an unrivaled market position, significant expansion potential and strong structural growth drivers. We believe the existing estate is justified by the current
share price and hence investors are getting growth potential for free.

BE

Sales – £1,078m vs forecast £1050m
EBIT - £90m vs forecast £82m
EPS – 7.3p vs forecast 6.3p
DPS - 1.55p vs forecast 1.57p - up 11%

BE

Growth and occupancy: Mature CC growth was 0.9% (vs 2% forecast and vs 2.7% in Q1). This implies growth went negative in Q2. Mature occupancy was
78.6% vs 78.5% last year. Overall Q2 growth did slow to 6.4% from 14.5% in Q1 – half of this is due to the baseline effect of acquisitions, with the other half
primarily from a softening of demand.
Gross margin – down 140bp to 20.9% reflecting large number of immature openings and we suspect a higher number of partnership agreements.

Overheads – Overhead leverage was excellent, with overheads actually falling 6% in absolute terms and as a % of sales from 15.4% to 12.6%.
EBITA margin – Up 150bp (vs 110bp forecast) reflecting the strong overhead control.
Capex – The group spent £83m on growth capex (113 new centres) and now has visibility on £120m and 350 centres so far for 2016 (as at May), so capex will
be very H1 weighted.
Cash flow/Debt – A very strong cashflow performance, with a WC inflow of c.£49m. Net debt is £174m (vs £191m at the year-end). The key banking facility has
been increased to £550m and extended to 2021.
ROI – Further ROIC improvement seen on the old estate and new openings progressing as expected.
Outlook – Trading is in line with expectations. There has been softening in revenue growth in some markets on the back of macro uncertainty but Regus has
planned prudently for 2016 and taken specific action early in the year to improve efficiencies across the business. Management remains confident in the long-
term drivers of the industry, newer locations are progressing in line and management remains focused on operational efficiency to deliver further scale benefits.

11:56 am
BE

And Caz most the analyst meeting.

BE

Regus’s 1H16 analyst meeting continued the themes from this morning’s
release of weakening topline, offset by very strong cost control. Regus’s
constant currency growth slowed from 14.5% in 1Q, to 6.4% in 2Q, and
management commented that the beginning of 3Q16 also shows c.6.4%
YoY growth. However, overheads are expected to decline further in
absolute CC terms in 2H16, with 1H16 overheads including a £5m
restructuring charge. We believe the overhead decline is a result of
reduced middle management from a move to a clustered sales approach,
and benefits from prior IT investments, particularly in customer service.
We remain Neutral on Regus with a December 2016 price target of 300p.

BE

Overheads expected to continue further. Regus’s 1H16 results
showed strong cost control, with overheads falling as a percentage of
revenue (12.6% for 1H16 after 14.1% in 2H16), and also falling 9% in
absolute constant currency terms, despite 10% CC revenue growth. We
believe that this large reduction in overhead was a result of the move to
a cluster management approach and the related ability to reduce the
middle management headcount, and the benefits from IT investment,
including the move to app-based customer service, which reduced call
centre costs. This performance is even more impressive in light of the
c.£5m restructuring cost that management expensed through overheads
in 1H16. As a result, management are confident that 2H16 overheads
will be lower than 1H16 in constant currency, irrespective of growth.
We currently model overheads in 2H16 in line with 1H16 with stronger
FX offsetting the underlying improvement. Management also believe
they can continue to reduce overheads at constant currency YoY in
coming years.

BE

H1 results were in-line with expectations. A softening in trading conditions leads
to an underlying earnings downgrade. However, an emphasis on cost efficiency,
cash generation, returns and a disciplined approach to capital allocation is positive
for the operating model over the medium term. On balance we believe the shares
appear up with events in the short term.

BE

● Numbers - H1 EBITA of £96m is in-line with management's expectations. Constant FX
revenue growth of 10% reflects a slowdown in Q2 to 6% from 15% in Q1. Mature centre
revenues were c.-1% YoY reflecting a widespread softening in market conditions.
Mature centre gross margins increased by 110bps reflecting the increasing maturity of
the 2014 centre additions, and a selective increase in price in markets such as the UK,
albeit at the expense of occupancy.
● Cost control - Operating costs declined by 9% on a underlying basis, ahead of our
expectations. The rewards of investment in IT, streamlining of the admin process and
greater organisational efficiency leave operating costs / sales at c.12.6% versus 15.4%
a year ago. We believe there is scope to go below the historic target range of 12-14%.
● Capital discipline - Growth capex guidance of £120m and c.350 centres has been
maintained. The impact of FX suggests an underlying reduction and greater proportion
of risk-sharing partnerships versus conventional leases. We view this as prudent capital
management, with an emphasis on returns and cash generation a significant driver
of investment decisions. We believe Regus' capital discipline has improved relative to
previous cycles.
● Forecasts - We lower our revenue growth assumptions but leave our FY16E EBITA
of £197m unchanged. This reflects a softening in trading conditions, but a greater
than expected reduction in the cost base. However, the benefit from an increasing FX
tailwind implies an underlying earnings downgrade of c.5%. Arguably Brexit poses an
additional threat, leaving the underlying earnings risk on the downside.
● Valuation & view - The focus on cost control, returns, and greater capital discipline are
encouraging. However, given the increasingly uncertain macro outlook and the breadth
of the slowdown experienced in Q2, we believe the shares are up with events in the
short term. We maintain our 300p target price, but lower our rating to Hold from Buy.

PM

FT reports Rank/888 has made a formal approach: The FT
reports that terms of a potential merger between William Hill (O/P), Rank and 888 (neither stock covered by CS) have been
submitted. The article notes a value of 364p per share as well as merger synergies that boost the value of the proposal to

William Hill board will recommend such a deal, largely due to the complexity of the merged entity and unaltered online/land
based revenue mix.

PM

Assessing the reported bid price and synergies: The FT has reported that the Rank and 888 consortium have submitted a
formal offer for William Hill at 364p per share (9% above current levels at 13:45 UK time) as well as outlining merger
synergies which could raise the value to 408p per share. We would expect any such deal to be structured as a merger
given the respective market caps involved and based on the 364p figure this implies a market cap for William Hill of £3.2bn
and a share of the combined equity of 66% (Rank mkt cap £834m, 888 market cap £803m). In considering the potential
synergies envisaged we take the difference between the 364p and 408p prices mentioned, which would indicate the value
to William Hill of its share of those synergies is £387m (44p x 880m shares). This implies a total pre-tax synergy value of
£730m (WMH share 66%, tax 20%). If this is the perpetuity value of synergies using a discount rate of 8%, it implies an
annual impact of c£60m equivalent to 2.2% of the combined 2015 revenues of the three companies. This compares to deal
synergies for Paddy Power Betfair (rated U/P) of 4% of revenues and Ladbrokes (rated Neutral) and Coral of 3%. Although
a value of 408p implies over 20% potential upside and is 65% above the lows of early July, we think William Hill is unlikely
to accept a deal.
